head.title: Disabled in America, Beyond Harvard; A Student's Promise

hedline.hl1: Disabled in America, Beyond Harvard; A Student's Promise

abstract.p: Barbara Quackenbos letter on May 17 article on quadriplegic Brooke Ellison's success at Harvard cites gains for all from inclusion of disabled

block.p: Re ''An Unrelenting Drive, and a Harvard Degree'' (front page, May 17):

The beautiful thing about inclusion of people with disabilities is that it is a classic ''win-win'' situation. Brooke Ellison gets to fulfill her fullest potential; Harvard gets to cultivate a broader intellectual and social climate than would otherwise be the case, benefiting everyone.
Re ''An Unrelenting Drive, and a Harvard Degree'' (front page, May 17):

The beautiful thing about inclusion of people with disabilities is that it is a classic ''win-win'' situation. Brooke Ellison gets to fulfill her fullest potential; Harvard gets to cultivate a broader intellectual and social climate than would otherwise be the case, benefiting everyone.

Ms. Ellison's classmates obviously recognize the degree to which their lives are enriched by exposure to her unique ideas, abilities and perspective; I presume that is why they voted for her to present a senior class day speech.
Harvard is to be commended for recognizing why inclusion of Ms. Ellison was a win-win. (Now it should make sure that all of its buildings are accessible to wheelchairs.)
Other institutions should take note of the fact that everyone benefits from an inclusive policy toward people with disabilities.
